etymologies: mid 17th century; earliest use found in Daniel Coxe (1640–1730), physician, natural philosopher, and colonial adventurer. From virtuoso + -ship

definitions: The state or condition of being a virtuoso; especially interest in the fine arts, connoisseurship. Compare "virtuosity".

notes.text: Frequently with negative connotations of superficial or trifling interest.

definitions: The qualities or abilities characteristic of a virtuoso; especially exceptional technical skill in music.

notes.text: Occasionally with negative connotations of the pursuit of technique at the expense of emotional depth or creativity.
